channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lawmakers Confront a Rise in Threats and Intimidation, and Fear Worse
item.description: Violent political speech has increasingly crossed into the realm of in-person confrontation for members of Congress in both parties, raising the prospect of a disastrous event.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Luke Broadwater and Carl Hulse
item.media:description: House and Senate leaders have their own security details, including plainclothes officers and armored vehicles, but it can be more difficult for rank-and-file lawmakers to obtain such protection.

item.title: Ukraine Forces Retake Lyman, a Strategic City, as Russians Retreat
item.description: Russia’s withdrawal from the city comes one day after Moscow illegally annexed the surrounding region.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Bakhmut on Saturday.

item.title: In Washington, Putin’s Nuclear Threats Stir Growing Alarm
item.description: In a gathering Cold War atmosphere, American officials are gaming out responses should Russia resort to battlefield nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia displayed on Friday on a screen in Moscow as he addressed the sham annexation of four regions of Ukraine.

item.title: Panic, Bribes, Ditched Cars and a Dash on Foot: Portraits of Flight From Russia
item.description: A mountain pass into Georgia has become a choke point for Russians fleeing the country, many of them men who faced being drafted and sent to fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ksenia Ivanova and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Ksenia Ivanova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei with his two children Daniil, 10, and Karina, 10, in a hotel room in Stepatsminda, Georgia.

item.title: Facing a Dire Storm Forecast in Florida, Officials Delayed Evacuation
item.description: A day of hesitation in Lee County came despite warnings that the Fort Myers and Cape Coral area could see mass flooding. Now authorities are encountering mass death.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Mike Baker, Serge F. Kovaleski and Lazaro Gamio
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tristan Stout, 22, surveying the damage to his father’s boat after it was moved across the street on San Carlos Island in Fort Myers Beach.

item.title: Some Florida Residents Face Long Gas Lines After Hurricane Ian
item.description: At one station, in Port Charlotte, cars stretched for over a mile, while hundreds of others in need carried cans. And lawn chairs.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: The line at a Wawa convenience store in Port Charlotte, Fla., on Saturday.

item.title: In Florida’s Fort Myers Area, Scenes of Paradise May Be Lost for Good
item.description: On Fort Myers Beach, Sanibel Island and Pine Island, cherished landmarks and an easygoing existence were obliterated by Hurricane Ian.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Reed, Patricia Mazzei and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers in Fort Myers Beach on Thursday.

item.title: American Prisoners Are Released From Venezuela and Iran
item.description: Caracas let go seven Americans in a trade for two nephews of Venezuela’s first lady who had been convicted on drug charges. Separately, Tehran freed its longest-held American prisoner.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The Americans released by Venezuela included several executives of the Citgo oil refining company who had been detained more than four years ago.

item.title: In China, Living Not ‘With Covid,’ but With ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: The country’s strict coronavirus restrictions dictate the patterns of daily life, like waiting in line for frequent Covid tests and stocking up on extra groceries in case of lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A Covid testing station in Beijing in September. The government ordered testing sites to be within a 15-minute walk in cities.

item.title: The Great Guinea Pig Giveaway Has Begun
item.description: From geckos to chinchillas, small pets were a pandemic balm. Now shelters across the country say they are being surrendered.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.category: American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liliana Bravo, an adoption supervisor at a New York City animal shelter, holds one of the many guinea pigs to be surrendered in recent weeks. The City Council is considering a bill that would ban their sale in pet shops.

item.title: In Michigan, Tudor Dixon Tests Whether Trump Is Help or Hindrance
item.description: Tudor Dixon, the party’s nominee for governor, has ground to make up in her race against Gov. Gretchen Whitmer. She is hoping the former president can rally their party’s base.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tudor Dixon won the Republican primary for governor of Michigan days after being endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Records From Trump White House Still Missing, National Archives Says
item.description: The archives said in a letter to the House Oversight Committee that it was seeking electronic messages from unnamed White House officials sent through personal accounts.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, the chairwoman of the House Oversight Committee, had requested an assessment of what presidential records remained unaccounted for.

item.title: Young and Homeless in Rural America
item.description: Most social services come through the schools — but it can be impossible to get to them.
item.dc:creator: Samantha M. Shapiro
item.media:credit: Danna Singer for The New York Times
item.media:description: After the rural Ohio apartment where Re’nae and Wade lived was condemned, their family bounced from motel to motel while looking for suitable housing.

item.title: The Optimistic Art of Mary Mattingly
item.description: The artist’s work addresses future climate crises while attempting to make the urban environment a better place to live right now.
item.dc:creator: Zoë Lescaze

item.title: Putin’s Speech Just Told Us His Ukraine War Plans
item.description: Amid the bluster and veiled threats, the president made three distinct points that form a blueprint for war and peace.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Baunov

item.title: Vladimir Putin’s ‘Medea’
item.description: What does Vlad the Impaler have in store for the world?
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin held a ceremony Friday to declare the annexation of four regions in Ukraine.

item.title: The Supreme Court Has a Crisis of Trust
item.description: A court that does not keep the public’s trust cannot perform its critical role in American government.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times

item.title: There Is a Tax That Could Help With Inflation
item.description: The case for a progressive levy on consumption.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times

item.title: Will Nostalgia Kill the British Right?
item.description: A yearning for the 1980s meets a very 21st century kind of European crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain.

item.title: How Private High Schools Keep the College Pay-to-Win Game Going
item.description: And it can be yours for just four yearly payments of $50,000!
item.dc:creator: Sophie Callcott

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Broken. Where’s Biden?
item.description: Why is the president sitting this out?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Shesol

item.title: The Global Indigenous Movement to Fight Climate Change
item.description: It’s time for Indigenous voices to lead the climate fight.
item.dc:creator: Camila Falquez and Isvett Verde

item.title: Dreaming of Spaghetti and (Meatless) Meatballs
item.description: Ricotta polpette, vegetarian Swedish meatballs and plant-based meatballs.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

item.title: A Strong Dollar Is Hurting Other Countries. Should the Fed Care?
item.description: Experts disagree.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: Did Your Home Security Camera Document Hurricane Ian?
item.description: We want to hear from you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction from Hurricane Ian on Thursday in Fort Myers Beach, Fla.

item.title: Juventus Learns That Progress Requires a Plan
item.description: Its coach rejects any sort of rigid style, preferring to mold his teams to their talent. But when things go bad, as they have in Turin, that lack of philosophy can leave a team to flounder.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: New Burkina Faso Coup Raises Question About Security
item.description: Unrest quickly escalated in Burkina Faso’s capital, Ouagadougou, as military officers who removed another military leader accused France of helping him stage a comeback.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Soldiers standing guard in an armored vehicle in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Saturday.

item.title: Backing Lindt, Swiss Court Orders Lidl to ‘Destroy’ Its Chocolate Bunnies
item.description: With Easter still far away, there are none to melt down. But the decision opened a door on the bunny-eat-bunny world of European chocolatiers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Lindt, the Swiss chocolate maker, is protective of its “Gold Bunny.”

item.title: Health Insurance Guide: Navigating Coverage in Your 20s
item.description: Whether you’re turning 26 and about to age out of a parent’s plan or just landing a job with benefits, finding coverage is a tricky task.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I decided to go with the lower-paying option with the expectation that I wouldn’t need as much care and would likely be better off,” said Cal Treichler, who bought his own insurance when he turned 26 this year.

item.title: British Ruling Pins Blame on Social Media for Teenager’s Suicide
item.description: The internet, according to the ruling, “affected her mental health in a negative way and contributed to her death in a more than minimal way.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Jonathan Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photo album of Molly Russell, who died in November 2017.

item.title: F.D.A. Moves to Change ‘Healthy’ Food Definition
item.description: Salmon is in; sugary yogurt is out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times

item.title: How to Strengthen Your Bones and Reduce Osteoporosis Risk
item.description: A new study predicts hip fractures will nearly double worldwide by 2050. Here’s how to avoid them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Hair Loss After Covid: What to Know
item.description: Increased shedding after illness is not unusual. The good news is that it’s most likely temporary.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: A Sneaker With a Built-In Puddle
item.description: Thinking about oceans of plastic at Paris Fashion Week.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
